Infinitives

The infinitive is a verbal noun. The present infinitive is the second principal part of a verb. When you encounter these, translate them as "to (verb)" (e.g. amare = to love and monere = to warn).

Complementary Infinitive: An infinitive used to complete an action of the sentence.

Latin examples:

  • Libros legere amo. I love to read books.

Imperatives

The imperative mood is used to form 2nd person singular or plural "commands." It is formed by using the present stem of the verb (second principal part minus -re).

The SINGULAR imperative is formed by dropping the -re from the 2nd principal part.

Examples:

Dictionary EntrySingular Imperative
amo, amare, amavi, amatus, -a, -um to loveama (love!)
doceo, docere, docui, doctus, -a, -um to teachdoce (teach!)
mitto, mittere, misi, missus, -a, -um to sendmitte (send!)
capio, capere, cepi, captus, -a, -um to seizecape (seize!)
audio, audire, audivi, auditus, -a, -um to hearaudi (hear!)

The PLURAL IMPERATIVE is formed by dropping the -re from the 2nd principal part and adding -te to the stem. Note that in the 3rd conjugation, we change the last -e- in the present stem into an -i prior to adding -te.

Examples:

Dictionary EntryPlural Imperative
amo, amare, amavi, amatus, -a, -um to loveamate (love!)
doceo, docere, docui, doctus, -a, -um to teachdocete (teach!)
mitto, mittere, misi, missus, -a, -um to sendmittite (send!)
capio, capere, cepi, captus, -a, -um to seizecapite (seize!)
audio, audire, audivi, auditus, -a, -um hearaudite (hear!)

Latin examples:

  • Romani, laudate Caesarem! Romans, praise Caesar!
  • Da mihi librum! Give the book to me!

Irregular Imperatives

Some verbs have irregular imperative forms that you must memorize.

Dictionary EntryIrregular Singular Imperative
duco, ducere, duxi, ductus, -a, -um to teachduc (teach!)
fero, ferre, tuli, latus, -a, -um to bringfer (bring!)
dico, dicere, dixi, dictus,-a, -um to saydic (say!)
facio, facere, feci, factus, -a, -um to dofac (do!)

Latin examples:

  • Populos duce! Lead the people!

  • Ad agricolas dic! Speak to the farmers!
